Agent Assist: AI tool that supports live human agents with real-time suggestions and information
Agent Tools: Capabilities that allow agents to interact with external systems and perform actions
AI Accountability: Establishing responsibility for AI system outcomes and decisions
AI Adoption: The process of implementing and using AI technologies within an organization
AI Agents: Software applications that achieve goals by observing the world and acting upon it using available tools
AI Bias: Systematic errors in AI outputs that reflect prejudices in training data or design
AI Ethics: Moral principles and guidelines governing the development and use of AI
AI Explainability: The ability to understand and explain how AI models arrive at their outputs
AI Fairness: Ensuring AI systems treat all individuals and groups equitably without discrimination
AI Governance: Policies and frameworks for managing AI development and deployment responsibly
AI Implementation: The practical deployment of AI solutions in business processes
AI KPIs (Key Performance Indicators): Metrics used to evaluate the success of AI initiatives
AI Principles: Published guidelines that direct the responsible development and deployment of AI
AI ROI (Return on Investment): Measuring the financial returns from AI investments
AI Transformation: The process of integrating AI throughout an organization's operations
AI Transparency: Making AI decision-making processes understandable and visible to users
AI Use Cases: Specific applications or scenarios where AI provides business value
AI-first Company: Organization that prioritizes AI in its strategy and operations
Anomaly Detection: Identifying unusual patterns or outliers in data
API (Application Programming Interface): Set of rules governing how software components interact and communicate
Apps Script: JavaScript-based platform for automating Google Workspace with AI capabilities
AppSheet: No-code platform for building custom business apps with AI features
Artificial Intelligence (AI): The broad field of computer science focused on creating machines capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence
Artificial Neural Networks: Mathematical models composed of interconnected nodes that process information using connectionist approaches
Augmentation vs Automation: Distinction between AI enhancing human capabilities versus replacing human tasks
AutoML: Automated machine learning that enables creation and training of models without extensive ML expertise
BERT: Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers - Google's language understanding model
BigQuery ML: Feature that allows building and executing ML models directly in BigQuery using SQL
Chain-of-Thought (CoT) Prompting: Guiding a model through problem-solving by providing examples with intermediate reasoning steps
Chatbots: AI-powered conversational interfaces that interact with users through text or voice
Chirp: Google's speech recognition foundation model trained on multiple languages
Classification Models: Models that categorize input data into predefined classes or categories
Cloud Computing: Delivery of computing services over the internet for AI training and deployment
Cloud Run: Serverless platform for deploying and running containerized applications
Cloud Run Functions: Serverless functions triggered by events for lightweight AI processing
Cloud Spanner: Globally distributed, strongly consistent database service
Cloud SQL: Managed relational database service for structured data storage
Cloud Storage: Scalable object storage service for AI training data and model artifacts
Cloud Video Intelligence API: API for analyzing video content and extracting meaningful information
Cloud Vision API: API for understanding and analyzing image content
Code Agents: AI agents that assist with writing, reviewing, debugging, and generating code
Code Generation: AI capability to write programming code based on natural language descriptions
CodeGemma: A Gemma variant specialized for code generation and understanding
Colab Enterprise: Enterprise version of Google Colab for collaborative notebook-based AI development
Contact Center as a Service (CCaaS): Cloud-based contact center solution with AI capabilities
Content Generation: Using AI to create text, images, videos, or other media automatically
Content Moderation: Reviewing and filtering AI-generated content for appropriateness and safety
Context Window: The amount of information a model can consider at one time when generating a response
Conversational Agents: Agents designed for natural language dialogue, answering questions and chatting with users
Conversational Agents (Dialogflow): Platform for building AI-powered chatbots and voice bots
Conversational Insights: Analytics tool for analyzing customer interactions and improving service
Creative Agents: AI agents that generate ideas, create content, and assist with creative tasks
Customer Engagement Suite: Google's comprehensive platform for AI-powered customer interactions
Customer Service Agents: AI agents that answer questions, resolve issues, and provide personalized recommendations
Data Accessibility: The availability, cost, and format considerations for obtaining and using data
Data Agents: AI agents that analyze datasets, identify trends, and extract insights from data
Data Governance: Policies and practices for managing data availability, usability, integrity, and security
Data Preprocessing: Cleaning and transforming raw data into a usable format
Data Privacy: Protecting personal and sensitive information used in AI systems
Data Quality: The accuracy, completeness, consistency, relevance, and representativeness of data
Data Stores: Knowledge bases that give agents access to real-time, historical, and domain-specific information
Deep Learning (DL): A specialized subset of machine learning that utilizes artificial neural networks with multiple layers to analyze complex data patterns
Deterministic Agents: Agents based on predefined paths and rules that always produce the same output for the same input
Diffusion Models: Generative models that create high-quality images, audio, and video through iterative refining of data and patterns
Document AI: AI service for extracting data and insights from various document formats
Drift Monitoring: Detecting changes in data or model performance over time
Edge Cases: Rare or atypical scenarios that can expose model weaknesses
Edge Computing: Running AI on devices or servers closer to the data source for real-time processing
Embeddings: Numerical representations of data (text, images) that capture semantic meaning in vector form
Employee Productivity Agents: AI agents that help workers find information, manage tasks, and automate workflows
Extensions (APIs): Tools that standardize agent interaction with external APIs and services
Feature Engineering: Creating and selecting relevant input variables for ML models
Few-shot Prompting: Providing the model with multiple examples to learn from before performing a task
Fine-tuning: Further training a pre-trained model on a new dataset specific to a particular task
Firestore: NoSQL document database for mobile, web, and server development
Forecasting: Predicting future values based on historical data patterns
Foundation Models: Large AI models trained on vast quantities of diverse data, capable of adapting to a variety of downstream tasks
Functions: Specialized, reusable actions within an agent's toolbox for specific tasks
Gemini: Google's multimodal AI model family that supports text, images, code, audio, and video understanding and generation
Gemini Advanced: Premium version of Gemini with enhanced capabilities for coding, logical reasoning, and creative collaboration
Gemini API: Interface for accessing Gemini model capabilities programmatically
Gemini App: Google's generative AI chatbot application powered by Gemini models
Gemini Cloud Assist: AI assistant for designing, managing, and optimizing applications on Google Cloud
Gemini Code Assist: AI pair programmer that provides code suggestions, generates code blocks, and offers explanations
Gemini Developer API: API for developers to integrate Gemini into their applications
Gemini Enterprise: Enterprise-grade platform for creating customized AI agents that access and understand company data
Gemini for Google Cloud: AI assistance integrated into Google Cloud services for development and operations
Gemini in BigQuery: AI assistance for data analysis, code writing, and insight generation in BigQuery
Gemini in Databases: AI assistance for database management and administration tasks
Gemini in Looker: AI-powered data analysis and visualization assistance in Looker
Gemini in Security: AI-powered security threat detection, analysis, and response assistance
Gemini Nano: A compact version of Gemini designed for on-device AI processing on mobile phones and edge devices
Gemini Pro: A powerful version of Gemini optimized for a wide range of tasks and scalability
Gemma: Google's open-source, lightweight AI model family designed for developers and local deployments
Gemma 2: Second generation of Google's open Gemma model family with improved performance
Generative AI (Gen AI): A type of artificial intelligence that can create new content, including images, text, audio, and code
Generative AI Agents: Agents powered by foundation models that can understand natural language and generate flexible responses
Google AI Studio: A web-based tool for developers to experiment with Gemini models and the Gemini Developer API
Google Workspace with Gemini: Integration of Gemini AI capabilities into Google Workspace apps like Gmail, Docs, Sheets, and Slides
GPUs (Graphics Processing Units): Specialized processors that excel at parallel processing, widely used for AI training and inference
Grounding: Connecting AI output to verifiable and specific sources of information to improve accuracy
Hallucinations: When AI models generate outputs that are not accurate or based on real information
High-performance Computing: Computing infrastructure optimized for intensive AI training and inference tasks
Human-in-the-Loop (HITL): Integrating human oversight and judgment into AI processes
Hypercomputers: Supercomputers built by connecting many nodes together for massive AI workloads
IAM (Identity and Access Management): Framework for managing user identities and access permissions
Image Generation: AI capability to create visual content from text descriptions or other inputs
Imagen: Google's text-to-image generation model that creates high-quality images from text descriptions
Inference: Using a trained model to make predictions on new data
Input/Output: The data provided to and generated by an AI model
Knowledge Cut-off: The last date that an AI model was trained on new information
Labeled Data: Data tagged with meaningful labels that enable supervised learning
Large Language Models (LLMs): Foundation models that understand and generate human language, trained on massive text datasets
Lite Runtime (LiteRT): Framework helping ML models work efficiently on edge devices and mobile phones
Machine Learning (ML): A subset of AI where machines learn from data without explicit programming, improving their performance over time
Machine Translation: Automatic translation of text or speech between languages
MLOps (Machine Learning Operations): Practices for deploying and maintaining ML models in production
Modality: The type of data a model can process (text, image, audio, video)
Model Deployment: Making trained models available for use in applications or services
Model Evaluation: Assessing model performance using metrics and test data
Model Garden: Vertex AI's repository of over 160 pre-trained models that can be discovered, customized, and deployed
Model Monitoring: Tracking deployed model performance and detecting degradation or drift
Model Refinement: Improving model performance through iterative adjustments
Model Training: The process of teaching an AI model using data
Model Tuning: Adjusting model parameters or training to improve performance for specific use cases
Model Versioning: Tracking and managing different versions of AI models
Multi-agent Systems: Systems utilizing multiple specialized agents that collaborate to achieve complex goals
Multimodal: Capability to process and generate multiple types of data simultaneously
Multimodal Models: AI models capable of processing and generating content across multiple types of data (text, images, video, audio)
Natural Language API: API for deriving insights from unstructured text
Natural Language Processing (NLP): AI field focused on enabling computers to understand and process human language
Natural Language Understanding: AI capability to comprehend the meaning and intent of human language
Neural Networks: Computing systems inspired by biological neural networks that learn to perform tasks by analyzing examples
NotebookLM: AI-powered research assistant that analyzes uploaded documents and provides grounded answers
NotebookLM Enterprise: Enterprise version with enhanced compliance, privacy, and administrative features
One-shot Prompting: Providing the model with one example before asking it to perform a task
Output Length: Parameter determining the maximum length of generated text
PaliGemma: A Gemma variant optimized for vision-language tasks
Plugins: Add-ons that extend agent capabilities by connecting to services and specialized tools
Pre-trained Models: AI models that have already been trained on large datasets and can be used directly or fine-tuned for specific tasks
Prediction: The output generated by a model based on input data
Prompt Chaining: Building conversations where each response builds upon the previous one for refined outcomes
Prompt Engineering: The practice of crafting precise prompts to guide AI models towards desired outputs
Pub/Sub: Real-time messaging service for streaming data ingestion
ReAct (Reason and Act) Prompting: Framework allowing models to reason and take action through thought-action-observation loops
Reasoning Loop: The iterative process where an agent observes, reasons, decides, and acts to complete tasks
Reinforcement Learning: ML approach where agents learn through interaction with an environment and feedback rewards
Responsible AI: Development and deployment of AI systems that are ethical, fair, and beneficial to society
REST API: Architectural style for designing networked applications using HTTP requests
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): Technique that retrieves relevant information from external sources to augment AI responses
Role Prompting: Assigning a specific role or persona to guide the AI's behavior, style, and tone
Safety Settings: Filters to prevent potentially harmful or inappropriate content in model outputs
Sampling Parameters: Settings that influence how models select tokens during text generation
SDK (Software Development Kit): Collection of tools and libraries for building applications with specific platforms
Secure AI Framework (SAIF): Google's comprehensive framework for building and deploying AI systems securely
Security Agents: AI agents that automate security tasks and threat detection
Semantic Search: Search that understands the meaning and context of queries rather than just keyword matching
Semi-supervised Learning: ML approach combining small amounts of labeled data with large amounts of unlabeled data
Sentiment Analysis: Determining the emotional tone or opinion expressed in text
Speech-to-Text: API service that converts audio speech into written text
Structured Data: Organized data that is easy to search, typically stored in tables with defined schemas
Supervised Learning: ML approach where models learn from labeled data with known correct answers
Temperature: Parameter controlling the randomness and creativity of model outputs (higher = more creative)
TensorFlow: Google's open-source machine learning framework for building and training ML models
Text Generation: AI capability to produce written content based on prompts or context
Text-to-Speech: API service that converts written text into natural-sounding speech
Token Count: The number of tokens in input or output, which affects model processing limits and costs
Tokens: Groups of characters (approximately 4 characters per token) that models use to process text
Top K: Parameter limiting word selection to the top K most probable tokens
Top P (Nucleus Sampling): Parameter setting the cumulative probability threshold for token selection
TPUs (Tensor Processing Units): Google's custom-designed processors optimized specifically for AI and machine learning workloads
Traditional AI Models: AI models trained for a single purpose using specific data, designed for particular tasks like spam filtering
Transfer Learning: Using knowledge gained from one task to improve performance on a different but related task
Unlabeled Data: Raw data without tags or labels, used in unsupervised learning
Unsupervised Learning: ML approach where models find patterns in unlabeled data without predefined answers
Vector Databases: Databases optimized for storing and querying high-dimensional vector embeddings
Veo: Google's video generation model that creates video content from text descriptions or images
Vertex AI: Google Cloud's unified AI development platform for building, training, and deploying ML models and AI applications
Vertex AI Feature Store: Service for sharing, serving, and reusing ML features to maintain consistency and efficiency
Vertex AI Model Registry: Tool for managing model versions, tracking changes, and organizing models throughout their lifecycle
Vertex AI Pipelines: Tool for automating and orchestrating end-to-end ML workflows
Vertex AI Recommendations: AI service for providing personalized product or content suggestions
Vertex AI Search: AI-powered search solution for enterprise data with generative AI features
Vertex AI Studio: A Google Cloud console tool for rapidly prototyping and testing generative AI models with enterprise security
Video Generation: AI capability to create video content from text, images, or other inputs
Voice Bots: AI systems that interact with users through spoken language
Workflow Agents: Agents that automate multi-step processes and handle complex task sequences
Zero-shot Prompting: Asking a model to complete a task with no examples provided
